newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots mostly lower.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots mostly lower.

text.p: Contracts on Shanghai's treasury bill repurchase market closed mostly lower on Monday on enlarged trading volume after a new A share issue on the Shenzhen stock exchange fanned short-term fund demand, traders said.
The annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract fell to 8.04 percent from 9.00 percent on Friday.
Total turnover on the six-contract market soared to 4.72 million lots from 1.74 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Shenzhen Hua Qiao Chen issued 45 million A shares for trading in Shenzhen, fuelling demand for short-term funds and particularly supporting the three-day contract, traders said.
"Heavy institutional borrowing pushed up both volume and rates of early-maturing contracts," one trader said.
The seven-day contract fell mainly due to institutional selling just before the close, and traders said they saw rates falling slightly in the next few days on a lack of market-moving news.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market ended mostly lower because the new A share issue sucked out short-term funds.
The most actively traded 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 rose to 112.74 yuan from 112.80 yuan.
Combined volume on the eight-contract market fell to 772,163 million lots from 1.47 million lots.
The strong performance of A share markets was another factor pushing down both volume and prices, traders said.
They said they expected the spots to linger around current levels in the next few days.
